Award.AwardTitle: Purification of Synthetic Peptides Using a Catching by Polymerization Approach
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Shiyue Fang of the Department of Chemistry at Michigan Technological University will explore the development of inexpensive and readily scalable methods for the purification of synthetic peptides. Besides wide applications in biological research, peptides are becoming more and more important in drug development. As a result, large quantities of peptides are needed. The most convenient method for peptide synthesis is to assemble amino acid monomers stepwise on a solid support using a synthesizer. In each monomer addition step, however, generation of truncated failure sequences is unavoidable. These failure sequences have similar physical properties as the full-length sequence and are therefore difficult to remove. The most widely used peptide purification method is reverse-phase HPLC. This method is labor intensive and consumes large volumes of organic solvents. In this project, two inexpensive and readily scalable peptide purification methods will be developed. In both methods, the desired full-length peptide will be modified with a polymerizable group. The failure sequences will not. After synthesis, the full-length peptide will be copolymerized into an insoluble polymer. The failure sequences will be removed by washing. Pure peptide will then be cleaved from the polymer.

Once developed, these purification technologies could be widely used for peptide drug purification. The price of many peptide drugs including those already on the market and the ones to be developed in the future could be lowered substantially. The project is interdisciplinary, requiring skills in organic synthesis, solid phase synthesis, peptide chemistry, and polymer science and provides a diverse training platform for students at all levels. Undergraduate students will be recruited from Finlandia University, which does not have an active research program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to extend the catching-by-polymerization synthetic DNA purification technologies to synthetic peptide purification. We have successfully developed the catching-full-length-sequence-by-polymerization method for peptide purification. Briefly, we synthesized a tagging agent that contains a polymerizable group. Using the agent, we attached a polymerizable group to full-length peptide products during automated solid phase synthesis. At purification, the product was co-polymerized into an insoluble polymer, and impurities were conveniently removed by washing. Pure product was then cleaved and extracted from the polymer. As indicated by analysis methods including high performance liquid chromatography, mass spectrometry and nucleic magnetic resonance spectrometry, the products have correct structure, and are highly pure. The recovery yields were also high. This new purification method does not need any type of chromatography, and purification is achieved with simple manipulations such as shaking, filtration and extraction. Therefore, it is expected to be suitable for large-scale purification of synthetic peptide drugs.

In the funding period, we also optimized the catching-by-polymerization synthetic DNA purification technologies. Among several accomplishments, the most significant was the development of a new tagging agent that made possible cleaving DNA product from polymer under more environmentally benign conditions. With the new tagging agent, we demonstrated the power of the catching-by-polymerization synthetic biopolymer purification technologies by purifying very long synthetic DNAs and by purifying at relatively large scales. For long DNA purification, we were able to isolate products with close to 200 nucleotide long (vs usually 20-60 nucleotide long) from complex crude mixtures. Such long synthetic DNAs could not be purified with the most widely used high performance liquid chromatography method. For large scale purification, we demonstrated that purification at hundred milligram scales is as convenient as purification at sub-milligram scales. The product has good purity and physical appearance, and the polymer waste amount is not large compared to the mass of DNA (see image). We expect that our progress on DNA purification will be helpful to encourage the community to use the catching-by-polymerization method for peptide purification.

Currently, there are over 60 peptide drugs on the market and over 500 in clinical trials. There are two FDA-approved DNA-based drugs and over 40 in clinical trials. The synthetic biopolymers are almost always purified with high performance liquid chromatography, which is expensive, and is estimated to cost about 30% of the total production expenses. The new catching-by-polymerization methods may be able to reduce the purification cost to half or less. Therefore, the project will benefit public health. Because synthetic DNA and peptide are widely used in research projects related to energy, national security, and agriculture, these areas will benefit from the project as well.

During the funding period, 11 undergraduate students, three graduate students, and three postdocs were trained in the areas of synthetic organic chemistry, peptide chemistry and nucleic acid chemistry. Among the undergraduate students, three were from community colleges where there are no research opportunities. One is an African American, and five are female. Among the graduate students and postdocs, three are female.
